Description></android.view.View__Product Description><android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.></android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.></android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the book:></android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the book:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__An all-new chapter on coding.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.></android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the community></android.view.View__Useful insight into submitting kernel patches and working with the Linux kernel community></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__About the Author></android.view.View__About the Author><android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.></android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.></android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. His other books include Linux System Programming and Linux in a Nutshell.></android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. up></android.view.View__Wrapping up></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__1. Resource sharing is the key!></android.view.View__1. Resource sharing is the key!><android.view.View__Let’s dive into the Linux component which is responsible for doing such great work: the scheduler.></android.view.View__Let’s dive into the Linux component which is responsible for doing such great work: the scheduler.><android.view.View__In order to do it, imagine what we would expect from an operating system. Let’s say that we’d want it to run tasks that we need to complete, providing the OS hardware resources. Tasks come of different natures but we can simply categorize them as CPU-intensive and interactive ones.></android.view.View__In order to do it, imagine what we would expect from an operating system. Let’s say that we’d want it to run tasks that we need to complete, providing the OS hardware resources. Tasks come of different natures but we can simply categorize them as CPU-intensive and interactive ones.><android.view.View__Something should provide the efficiency of task completion and responsiveness. Consider a typewriter that prints letters with 1s second of delay, it would be impossible to use! So, in a few words, I would like to request to the scheduler: “I want to execute this task and I want it’s completed when I need or to respond when I need”. The goal of a scheduler is to decide “what runs next” leading to have the best balance between the needings of the different natures of the tasks.></android.view.View__Something should provide the efficiency of task completion and responsiveness. Consider a typewriter that prints letters with 1s second of delay, it would be impossible to use! So, in a few words, I would like to request to the scheduler: “I want to execute this task and I want it’s completed when I need or to respond when I need”. The goal of a scheduler is to decide “what runs next” leading to have the best balance between the needings of the different natures of the tasks.><android.view.View__As Linux is a preemptive multitasking operating system, the completely fair scheduler (CFS) came to Linux, as the replacement of the O(1) scheduler from the 2.6.23, with the aim to guarantee the fairness of CPU owning by the tasks, and at the same time tailoring to a broad nature range of tasks. Although the algorithm complexity didn’t see an improvement, from O(1) to O(log N), the reduced latency removed issues when dealing with interactive tasks.></android.view.View__As Linux is a preemptive multitasking operating system, the completely fair scheduler (CFS) came to Linux, as the replacement of the O(1) scheduler from the 2.6.23, with the aim to guarantee the fairness of CPU owning by the tasks, and at the same time tailoring to a broad nature range of tasks. Although the algorithm complexity didn’t see an improvement, from O(1) to O(log N), the reduced latency removed issues when dealing with interactive tasks.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__As a side note consider that the Linux scheduler is made of different ></android.view.View__As a side note consider that the Linux scheduler is made of different ><android.view.View__scheduler classes></android.view.View__scheduler classes><android.view.View__ (></android.view.View__ (><android.view.View__code></android.view.View__code><android.view.View__), of which the ></android.view.View__), of which the ><android.view.View__CFS class></android.view.View__CFS class><android.view.View__ is the highest-priority one. Another one is the ></android.view.View__ is the highest-priority one. Another one is the ><android.view.View__real-time></android.view.View__real-time><android.view.View__ scheduler class, tailored as the name suggests for tasks that need responsiveness.></android.view.View__ scheduler class, tailored as the name suggests for tasks that need responsiveness.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Interactive tasks would run for small amounts of time but need to run quickly as events happen. CPU-intensive tasks don’t require to complete ASAP but require longer CPU time. Based on that, time accounting is what guarantees fairness in the Linux CFS scheduler as long as the task that runs for less time will run next.></android.view.View__Interactive tasks would run for small amounts of time but need to run quickly as events happen. CPU-intensive tasks don’t require to complete ASAP but require longer CPU time. Based on that, time accounting is what guarantees fairness in the Linux CFS scheduler as long as the task that runs for less time will run next.><android.view.View__This comes to the time accounting, so let’s start to dig into it!></android.view.View__This comes to the time accounting, so let’s start to dig into it!><android.view.View__2. Time accounting></android.view.View__2. Time accounting><android.view.View__Linux CFS actually does not directly assign timeslices to tasks as the O(1) scheduler did, instead it measures execution time, in order to be flexible with respect to both interactive and processor-intensive tasks.></android.view.View__Linux CFS actually does not directly assign timeslices to tasks as the O(1) scheduler did, instead it measures execution time, in order to be flexible with respect to both interactive and processor-intensive tasks.><android.view.View__The runtime></android.view.View__The runtime><android.view.View__Remember, the fundamental rule in the Completely Fair Scheduler is: the task that ran less, will run next! Which is, each task should have its fair slice of processor time when it needs! For example, interactive tasks can run frequently but for less time than intensive ones, and still have their fair amount of CPU time.></android.view.View__Remember, the fundamental rule in the Completely Fair Scheduler is: the task that ran less, will run next! Which is, each task should have its fair slice of processor time when it needs! For example, interactive tasks can run frequently but for less time than intensive ones, and still have their fair amount of CPU time.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The implementation is written in the></android.view.View__The implementation is written in the><android.view.View__update_curr()></android.view.View__update_curr()><android.view.View__ function, which is called periodically to account tasks for the CPU time they used in the last period (></android.view.View__ function, which is called periodically to account tasks for the CPU time they used in the last period (><android.view.View__delta_exec></android.view.View__delta_exec><android.view.View__).></android.view.View__).></android.view.View__><android.view.View__The virtual runtime></android.view.View__The virtual runtime><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The execution time is ></android.view.View__The execution time is ><android.view.View__further weighted></android.view.View__further weighted><android.view.View__ to implement priority between tasks. The more the weight, the more time the task will have.></android.view.View__. The more the weight, the more time the task will have.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Example></android.view.View__Example><android.view.View__Let' do an example with timeslices: considering a single CPU, if every T time period two tasks A and B run respectively with a weight of 1 and 2, the allocated CPU time is obtained by multiplying T by the ratio of the weight to the sum of the weights of all running tasks:></android.view.View__Let' do an example with timeslices: considering a single CPU, if every T time period two tasks A and B run respectively with a weight of 1 and 2, the allocated CPU time is obtained by multiplying T by the ratio of the weight to the sum of the weights of all running tasks:><android.view.View__CPU_timeslice(A) = T * (1 / (1 + 2))).
CPU_timeslice(B) = T * (2 / (1 + 2))).
></android.view.View__CPU_timeslice(A) = T * (1 / (1 + 2))).
CPU_timeslice(B) = T * (2 / (1 + 2))).
><android.view.View__For each T time period, task A will run for 0.334~T and task B 0.667~T.></android.view.View__For each T time period, task A will run for 0.334~T and task B 0.667~T.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This is what is calculated ></android.view.View__This is what is calculated ><android.view.View__here></android.view.View__here><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Implementation></android.view.View__Implementation><android.view.View__Coming to the actual implementation, the CFS class accounts tasks for their real execution time considering their weight, which is ensured by periodically measuring the runtime and multiplying it by the ratio weight/(base weight).></android.view.View__Coming to the actual implementation, the CFS class accounts tasks for their real execution time considering their weight, which is ensured by periodically measuring the runtime and multiplying it by the ratio weight/(base weight).><android.view.View__runtime += runtime * (w / base w)).
></android.view.View__runtime += runtime * (w / base w)).
><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Which is exactly what is done in ></android.view.View__Which is exactly what is done in ><android.view.View__update_curr()></android.view.View__update_curr()><android.view.View__:></android.view.View__:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__static void update_curr(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
	...
	delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
	...
	curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
	...
}
></android.view.View__static void update_curr(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{

	...
	delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
	...
	curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
	...
}

The bigger the depth of the hierarchy, the more the weight gets diluted. Adding a heavily weighted task to one child group is not going to afflict the overall tasks tree the same as it would do if it was part of the root group. This is because the task weight is relative to the group which the task is put into.></android.view.View__For the sake of simplicity let’s remember this: the groups are hierarchical, and a task is part of a task group. The bigger the depth of the hierarchy, the more the weight gets diluted. Adding a heavily weighted task to one child group is not going to afflict the overall tasks tree the same as it would do if it was part of the root group. This is because the task weight is relative to the group which the task is put into.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Each entity, whether a task or a task group, is treated the same. The time accounting is applied ></android.view.View__Each entity, whether a task or a task group, is treated the same. and ><android.view.View__recursively up through the hierarchy></android.view.View__recursively up through the ><android.view.View__task groups></android.view.View__task groups><android.view.View__ can be run on multiple CPUs doing real multitasking, the weight (i.e. CPU shares) for task group’s runqueue is updated><android.view.View__ (scaled) in></android.view.View__ (scaled) in><android.view.View__entity_tick()></android.view.View__entity_tick()><android.view.View__ based on how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.></android.view.View__ based on how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The weight is multiplied by the ratio of the ></android.view.View__The weight is multiplied by the ratio of the ><android.view.View__load></android.view.View__load><android.view.View__ of the task group running on the local CPU (which is the task group’s runqueue) to the global load of the task group.></android.view.View__ of the task group running on the local CPU (which is the task group’s runqueue) to the global load of the task group.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__This ratio tells us how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.></android.view.View__This ratio tells us how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__As a detail, ></android.view.View__As a detail, ><android.view.View__this is done></android.view.View__this is done><android.view.View__ if configured Linux for symmetrical multiprocessor, otherwise the></android.view.View__ if configured Linux for symmetrical multiprocessor, otherwise the><android.view.View__shares></android.view.View__shares><android.view.View__is not scaled></android.view.View__is not scaled><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__In detail, the load is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group or the task group’s runqueue.></android.view.View__In detail, the load is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group or the task group’s runqueue.><android.view.View__shares = shares * (runqueue's load / task group's load)
></android.view.View__shares = shares * (runqueue's load / task group's load)
><android.view.View__TL;DR: the ratio is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the runqueues to the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group:></android.view.View__TL;DR: the ratio is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the runqueues to the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group:><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The calculcation is done by the></android.view.View__The calculcation is done by the><android.view.View__calc_group_shares()></android.view.View__calc_group_shares()><android.view.View__ function, to get the final value of the task group’s shares that will weight the virtual runtime of the task group schedule entity:></android.view.View__ function, to get the final value of the task group’s shares that will weight the virtual runtime of the task group schedule entity:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
	/
	struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;

	/*
	   tg_shares is the task group's CPU shares.
	 */
	tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);

	/*
	   load is the load of the local CFS runqueue which is,
	   the load of the task group on the local CPU.
	 */
	load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);

	/*
	   tg_weight is the global load of the task group.
	 */
	tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);

	/* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
	tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
	tg_weight += load;

	shares = (tg_shares * load);
	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

	// ...

	/*
	   shares is now the per CPU-scaled task group shares.
	*/
	return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
}
></android.view.View__static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
	/
	struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;

	/*
	   tg_shares is the task group's CPU shares.
	 */
	tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);

	/*
	   load is the load of the local CFS runqueue which is,
	   the load of the task group on the local CPU.
	 */
	load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);

	/*
	   tg_weight is the global load of the task group.
	 */
	tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);

	/* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
	tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
	tg_weight += load;

	shares = (tg_shares * load);
	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

	// ...

	/*
	   shares is now the per CPU-scaled task group shares.
	*/
	return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
}
><android.view.View__This is done to treat fairly also groups among CPUs!></android.view.View__This is done to treat fairly also groups among CPUs!><android.view.View__...

	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;
...

	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;
...

 * Called by the timer interrupt handler every 1/HZ seconds.
 */
scheduler_tick()
/* The local CPU */
-> int cpu = smp_processor_id();
/* The local CPU runqueue */
-> struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
/* The local CPU runqueue currently running task */
-> struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
/* The current running task's scheduler class' periodic tick function. */
-> curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr)
   /* Let's assume the class is CFS. */
   -> task_tick_fair()
      -> struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
      /*
       * For each schedule entity through parent task groups
       * up to the root task group.
       */
      -> for_each_sched_entity(se)
         /* The runqueue where the entity is placed. */
         -> cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
         -> entity_tick(cfs_rq, se)
            /*
             * Update the virtual runtime for the current running entity
             * on the current selected by loop-task group's runqueue.
             */
            -> update_curr(cfs_rq)
               -> struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
               -> delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
               -> curr->exec_start = now;
               -> curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
            /*
             * If it's a task group update the shares 
             * based on its group runqueue,
             * which is the group load on the local CPU
             */
            -> update_cfs_group(se)
               /* The CFS runqueue of the entity, if it's a task group. */
               -> struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
               /* If the entity is a task, skip */
               -> if (!gcfs_rq)
               ->   return;
               /*
                * Update the CPU shares for the task group entity.
                */
               -> shares = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
               -> reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);
></android.view.View__/*
 * Called by the timer interrupt handler every 1/HZ seconds.
 */
scheduler_tick()
/* The local CPU */
-> int cpu = smp_processor_id();
/* The local CPU runqueue */
-> struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
/* The local CPU runqueue currently running task */
-> struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
/* The current running task's scheduler class' periodic tick function. */
-> curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr)
   /* Let's assume the class is CFS. */
   -> task_tick_fair()
      -> struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
      /*
       * For each schedule entity through parent task groups
       * up to the root task group.
       */
      -> for_each_sched_entity(se)
         /* The runqueue where the entity is placed. */
         -> cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
         -> entity_tick(cfs_rq, se)
            /*
             * Update the virtual runtime for the current running entity
             * on the current selected by loop-task group's runqueue.
             */
            -> update_curr(cfs_rq)
               -> struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
               -> delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
               -> curr->exec_start = now;
               -> curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
            /*
             * If it's a task group update the shares 
             * based on its group runqueue,
             * which is the group load on the local CPU
             */
            -> update_cfs_group(se)
               /* The CFS runqueue of the entity, if it's a task group. */
               -> struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
               /* If the entity is a task, skip */
               -> if (!gcfs_rq)
               ->   return;
               /*
                * Update the CPU shares for the task group entity.
                */
               -> shares = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
               -> reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);

><android.view.View__As a detail, wake up can be provoked in both process context and interrupt context, during an interrupt handler execution, which is what often device drivers do. Jargon></android.view.View__Functional Programming Jargon><android.view.View__Functional programming (FP) provides many advantages, and its popularity has been increasing as a result. However, each programming paradigm comes with its own unique jargon and FP is no exception. By providing a glossary, we hope to make learning FP easier.></android.view.View__Functional programming (FP) provides many advantages, and its popularity has been increasing as a result. However, each programming paradigm comes with its own unique jargon and FP is no exception. By providing a glossary, we hope to make learning FP easier.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Examples are presented in JavaScript (ES2015).></android.view.View__Examples are presented in into a function that takes them one at a time.></android.view.View__The process of converting a function that takes multiple arguments into a function that takes them one at a time.><android.view.View__Each time the function is called it only accepts one argument and returns a function that takes one argument until all arguments are passed.></android.view.View__Each time Currying></android.view.View__Auto Currying><android.view.View__Transforming a function that takes multiple arguments into one that if given less than its correct number of arguments returns a function that takes the rest. When the function gets the correct number of arguments it is then evaluated.></android.view.View__Transforming a function that takes multiple arguments into one that if given less than its correct number of arguments returns a function that takes the rest. When the function gets the correct number of arguments it is then evaluated.><android.view.View__lodash & Ramda have a curry function that works this way.></android.view.View__lodash & Ramda have a curry function that works this way.><android.view.View__constadd=(x,y)=>x+yconstcurriedAdd=_.curry(add)curriedAdd(1,2)// 3curriedAdd(1)// (y) => 1 + ycurriedAdd(1)(2)// 3></android.view.View__constadd=(x,y)=>x+yconstcurriedAdd=_.curry(add)curriedAdd(1,2)// 3curriedAdd(1)// (y) => 1 + ycurriedAdd(1)(2)// 3><android.view.View__Further reading></android.view.View__Further reading><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Favoring Curry></android.view.View__Favoring Curry></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Hey Underscore, You're Doing It Wrong!></android.view.View__Hey Underscore, You're Doing It Wrong!></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Function Composition></android.view.View__Function Composition><android.view.View__The act of putting two functions together to form a third function where the output of one function is the input of the other. The response is often passed off to the rest of the program, which is the continuation, once it's been received.></android.view.View__Continuations are often seen in asynchronous programming when the program needs to wait to receive data before it can continue. The function must always return the same result when given the same input.></android.view.View__A function is pure if the return value is only determined by its input values, and does not produce side effects. A.K.A Tacit programming.></android.view.View__. A.K.A Tacit programming.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// Givenconstmap=(fn)=>(list)=>list.map(fn)constadd=(a)=>(b)=>a+b// Then// Not point-free - `numbers` is an explicit argumentconstincrementAll=(numbers)=>map(add(1))(numbers)// Point-free - The list is an implicit argumentconstincrementAll2=map(add(1))></android.view.View__// Givenconstmap=(fn)=>(list)=>list.map(fn)constadd=(a)=>(b)=>a+b// Then// Not point-free - `numbers` is an explicit argumentconstincrementAll=(numbers)=>map(add(1))(numbers)// Point-free - The list is an implicit argumentconstincrementAll2=map(add(1))><android.view.View__Point-free function definitions look just like normal assignments without function or =>. It's worth mentioning that point-free functions are not necessarily better than their counterparts, as they can be more difficult to understand when complex.></android.view.View__Point-free function definitions look just like normal assignments without function or =>. It's worth mentioning that point-free functions are not necessarily better than their counterparts, as they can be more difficult to understand when complex.><android.view.View__Predicate></android.view.View__Predicate><android.view.View__A predicate is a function that returns true or false for a given value. A common use of a predicate is as the callback for array filter.></android.view.View__A predicate is a function that returns true or false for a given value. This acts as a set of rules that are expected from the input and output of a function or expression, and errors are generally reported whenever a contract is violated.></android.view.View__A contract specifies the obligations and guarantees of the behavior from a function or expression at runtime. In functional languages, this allows for structures like infinite lists, which would not normally be available in an imperative language where the sequencing of commands is significant.></android.view.View__Lazy evaluation is a call-by-need evaluation mechanism that delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__ which is not defined for all arguments - it might return an unexpected result or may never terminate. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded><android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions></android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ></android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ><android.view.View__Option></android.view.View__Option><android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ></android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ><android.view.View__Some(value)></android.view.View__Some(value)><android.view.View__ or ></android.view.View__ or ><android.view.View__None></android.view.View__None><android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything><android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.></android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. can’t believe that I can prove that it can sort></android.view.View__I can’t believe that I can prove that it can sort><android.view.View__by , – Jun 23, 2022><android.view.View__by></android.view.View__by><android.view.View__Yannick Moy ></android.view.View__Yannick Moy ><android.view.View__, ></android.view.View__, ><android.view.View__Lionel Matias ></android.view.View__Lionel Matias ><android.view.View__– ></android.view.View__– ><android.view.View__Jun 23, 2022></android.view.View__Jun 23, 2022></android.view.View__by , – Jun 23, 2022><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sorting algorithms are to computer science what “Hello World!” is to programming. A way for beginners to get their hands dirty. Which also means that most programmers don’t write “Hello World!” programs past their studies, and computer scientists don’t look at sorting algorithms past their PhD.></android.view.View__Sorting algorithms are to computer science what “Hello World!” is to programming. A way for beginners to get their hands dirty. Which also means that most programmers don’t write “Hello World!” programs past their studies, and computer scientists don’t look at sorting algorithms past their PhD.><android.view.View__Which made it surprising that a new “interesting” sorting algorithm was published at the end of 2021, whose appeal drew attention from both computer scientists and programmers. Here is the algorithm in full details:></android.view.View__Which made it surprising that a new “interesting” sorting algorithm was published at the end of 2021, whose appeal drew attention from both computer scientists and programmers. Here is the algorithm in full details:><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Screenshot-from-2022-06-22-11-25-54></android.view.View__Screenshot-from-2022-06-22-11-25-54></android.view.View__><android.view.View__As an expert user of Ada, and an anecdotal user of SPARK, one of us (Lionel) took it as a challenge to try some functional proof with SPARK. Despite a hopeful start, this ended up badly. As a SPARK expert thus contacted to help with the challenge, one of us (Yannick) took it as a way to show how functional proof should be approached in SPARK. Including some false starts, this ended up well (and under an hour). This is the story of this challenge, and the tips we think are important to share with those who aim at functional proof with SPARK.></android.view.View__As an expert user of Ada, and an anecdotal user of SPARK, one of us (Lionel) took it as a challenge to try some functional proof with SPARK. Despite a hopeful start, this ended up badly. As a SPARK expert thus contacted to help with the challenge, one of us (Yannick) took it as a way to show how functional proof should be approached in SPARK. Including some false starts, this ended up well (and under an hour). This is the story of this challenge, and the tips we think are important to share with those who aim at functional proof with SPARK.><android.view.View__I am Lionel, I’ll start.></android.view.View__I am Lionel, I’ll start.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__I recently stumbled upon a ></android.view.View__I recently stumbled upon a ><android.view.View__tweet about a paper on an “unbelievable” sorting algorithm></android.view.View__tweet about a paper on an “unbelievable” sorting algorithm><android.view.View__:></android.view.View__:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Screenshot-from-2022-06-22-11-31-26></android.view.View__Screenshot-from-2022-06-22-11-31-26></android.view.View__><android.view.View__I read the paper intro, and couldn’t realize what was wrong with it instinctively, but quickly seeing all the replies to the tweet brought back memories of learning programming, writing cool (at the time) programs for years, and then later on getting some formal computer science education.></android.view.View__I read the paper intro, and couldn’t realize what was wrong with it instinctively, but quickly seeing all the replies to the tweet brought back memories of learning programming, writing cool (at the time) programs for years, and then later on getting some formal computer science education.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__I dug up my first ever sorting algorithm. I’d used it in a silly 3D renderer that I’d implemented in 2000 on a Pentium 75, all implemented from scratch from what some might call nowadays “first principles” (i.e. I had absolutely no clue what I was doing). In a 3D renderer, once you’ve got your list of triangles to paint, and the direction of the camera set up, you want to z-sort the triangles so you can run the ></android.view.View__I dug up my first ever sorting algorithm. I’d used it in a silly 3D renderer that I’d implemented in 2000 on a Pentium 75, all implemented from scratch from what some might call nowadays “first principles” (i.e. I had absolutely no clue what I was doing). In a 3D renderer, once you’ve got your list of triangles to paint, and the direction of the camera set up, you want to z-sort the triangles so you can run the ><android.view.View__Painter algorithm></android.view.View__Painter algorithm><android.view.View__ (Wikipedia here is very generous, and calls it “depth-sort algorithm”). I needed a sort algorithm and I had no books, just my C compiler, SDL headers and some old French magazines about setting up VESA…></android.view.View__ (Wikipedia here is very generous, and calls it “depth-sort algorithm”). I needed a sort algorithm and I had no books, just my C compiler, SDL headers and some old French magazines about setting up VESA…></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__So I built one. I mean I built this one, and to me it looked like it worked. If you look at ></android.view.View__So I built one. I mean I built this one, and to me it looked like it worked. If you look at ><android.view.View__this video></android.view.View__this video><android.view.View__, it makes sense, somehow, especially for small array sizes, for a beginner that has no notion of smart sorting, big-O notation and no internet. My “unit tests” (generous term again) from the time show how little I understood about testing because they seem to be chosen></android.view.View__, it makes sense, somehow, especially for small array sizes, for a beginner that has no notion of smart sorting, big-O notation and no internet. My “unit tests” (generous term again) from the time show how little I understood about testing because they seem to be chosen><android.view.View__for ></android.view.View__for ><android.view.View__this algorithm (to validate this implementation and not sorting in general).></android.view.View__this algorithm (to validate this implementation and not sorting in general).></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__I’d put it together without videos and all the></android.view.View__I’d put it together without videos and all the><android.view.View__fancy></android.view.View__fancy><android.view.View__visualizations></android.view.View__visualizations><android.view.View__one can use></android.view.View__one can use><android.view.View__ when learning sorting algorithms, and I didn’t think about this code for years afterwards.></android.view.View__ when learning sorting algorithms, and I didn’t think about this code for years afterwards.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When I later learned Ada, first year of formal studies, I needed a sort function for a project and I just ported that algorithm and went with it (and I lived with it until I some month later I had to sort 2 millions entries and after a night at 100% CPU with almost no progress, I caved and cracked my copy of Sedgewick and started learning the science and not just the hacking-stuff-up).></android.view.View__When I later learned Ada, first year of formal studies, I needed a sort function for a project and I just ported that algorithm and went with it (and I lived with it until I some month later I had to sort 2 millions entries and after a night at 100% CPU with almost no progress, I caved and cracked my copy of Sedgewick and started learning the science and not just the hacking-stuff-up).><android.view.View__Paraphrasing the old code, it looked very simple:></android.view.View__Paraphrasing the old code, it looked very simple:><android.view.View__procedure Stupid_Sort
is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__procedure Stupid_Sort
is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)></android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)><android.view.View__
></android.view.View__
></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?></android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time.            ("-gnata",     -- enable assertions and runtime checks

    end Compiler;

    end Compiler;

  with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)
is
   Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
begin
   A (I) := A (J);
   A (J) := Tmp;
end Swap;></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)

begin
   A (I) := A (J);
   A (J) := Tmp;
end Swap;><android.view.View__… which (spoiler) wasn’t a very good idea (see “framing conditions”, later). Remember the postcondition he wrote for Swap:></android.view.View__Let’s return first to the addition of the Swap procedure in Lionel’s code. Remember the postcondition he wrote for Swap:><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)><android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.></android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the></android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the><android.view.View__frame condition></android.view.View__frame condition><android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)><android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.></android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.><android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition></android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition><android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.></android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:></android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:><android.view.View__
></android.view.View__

Lionel, I did not aim at rediscovering how the algorithm worked by looking at the code. Instead, I took the time to read the short article, and to convince myself that I understood why it worked.><android.view.View__Tip: Understand the code that you want to prove></android.view.View__Tip: Understand the code that you want to prove><android.view.View__Well, at least I thought I understood the algorithm. More on that later.></android.view.View__Well, at least I thought I understood the algorithm. More on that later.><android.view.View__I started by defining suitable types for the index of the array, one being slightly larger than the other, in order to accommodate empty ranges of values (when we start the iteration):></android.view.View__I started by defining suitable types for the index of the array, one being slightly larger than the other, in order to accommodate empty ranges of values (when we start the iteration):><android.view.View__type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. 5;
subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;></android.view.View__type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. 5;
subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;><android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints></android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints><android.view.View__Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.></android.view.View__Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.><android.view.View__Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.></android.view.View__Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.><android.view.View__function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;></android.view.View__function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;><android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties></android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties><android.view.View__In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.></android.view.View__In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.><android.view.View__The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.></android.view.View__The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.><android.view.View__Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:></android.view.View__Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:><android.view.View__(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))></android.view.View__(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))><android.view.View__But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.></android.view.View__But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.><android.view.View__Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers></android.view.View__Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers><android.view.View__With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:></android.view.View__With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));><android.view.View__It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!></android.view.View__It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));><android.view.View__And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):></android.view.View__And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));><android.view.View__Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove></android.view.View__Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove><android.view.View__It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.></android.view.View__It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.><android.view.View__As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.></android.view.View__As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.><android.view.View__Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them></android.view.View__Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them><android.view.View__Just looking at the failing loop invariant, I realized that it could not be true during the first iteration of the loop, where we have not yet identified the maximum value of the array. So I added a special case for I=A’First:></android.view.View__Just looking at the failing loop invariant, I realized that it could not be true during the first iteration of the loop, where we have not yet identified the maximum value of the array. So I added a special case for I=A’First:><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
  (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
  (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));><android.view.View__But the test was still failing at runtime! This time, I ran the test in the debugger (gdb inside GNAT Studio), to display values of all variables when hitting the failing loop invariant. That was a case of off-by-one error, the test “J < I” in the definition of constant M should be “J < I-1”. With that, the test was running without error.></android.view.View__But the test was still failing at runtime! With that, the test was running without error.><android.view.View__Tip: Debug failing assertions by running tests with assertions in the debugger></android.view.View__Tip: Debug failing assertions by running tests with assertions in the debugger><android.view.View__I reran GNATprove on the code. It reported cases of runtime errors when calling functions Sorted/Is_Max, which I fixed. But GNATprove could still not prove the loop invariant of the internal loop stating that A remained sorted from A’First to I-1. I read again the explanations in the article, which confirmed that it was true. Yet it was not proved. So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:></android.view.View__I reran GNATprove on the code. It reported cases of runtime errors when calling functions Sorted/Is_Max, which I fixed. But GNATprove could still not prove the loop invariant of the internal loop stating that A remained sorted from A’First to I-1. I read again the explanations in the article, which confirmed that it was true. Yet it was not proved. So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (if J < I then
      (for all K in A'First .. J => A(K) <= A(I)));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (if J < I then
      (for all K in A'First .. ></android.view.View__
></android.view.View__><android.view.View__pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Posted in ></android.view.View__Posted in ><android.view.View__#SPARK></android.view.View__#SPARK><android.view.View__    ></android.view.View__    ><android.view.View__#Proof></android.view.View__#Proof><android.view.View__    ></android.view.View__    ><android.view.View__#Algorithms></android.view.View__#Algorithms><android.view.View__   ></android.view.View__   ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__About ><android.view.View__About ></android.view.View__About ><android.view.View__Yannick Moy></android.view.View__Yannick Moy></android.view.View__About ><android.widget.Image__Yannick Moy></android.widget.Image__Yannick Moy><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Yannick Moy is Static Analysis Lead at AdaCore. I don’t feel like joining the incumbent tone or risk making a neophyte’s impostor syndrome worse than it already is.><android.view.View__The Code in Question></android.view.View__The Code in Question><android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.></android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.><android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}
></android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}
