></android.view.View__— Paul Moore (@Paul_Reviews) ><android.view.View__June 18, 2022></android.view.View__June 18, 2022></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__How to Review Cryptographic Protocols></android.view.View__How to Review Cryptographic Protocols><android.view.View__Whenever you are confronted with a novel cryptographic implementation (be it a custom protocol or a greenfield implementation of a standard design), always start with the reader, not the writer.></android.view.View__Whenever you are confronted with a novel cryptographic implementation (be it a custom protocol or a greenfield implementation of a standard design), always start with the reader, not the writer.><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.></android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.></android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.><android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__The reasoning is simple: In most threat models, attackers have control over the data being fed into the reader. This lets them perform far more impactful attacks (e.g. padding oracle attacks) than passing information to the writer would reveal (i.e. chosen-plaintext attacks, which overwhelmingly aren’t relevant for protocols that use standard cryptographic algorithms; i.e. AES).></android.view.View__The reasoning is simple: In most threat models, attackers have control over the data being fed into the reader. This lets them perform far more impactful attacks (e.g. padding oracle attacks) than passing information to the writer would reveal (i.e. chosen-plaintext attacks, which overwhelmingly aren’t relevant for protocols that use standard cryptographic algorithms; i.e. AES).><android.view.View__In this case, the pervade_decrypt() function is clearly written in order to support a data format migration from the original implementation to the new format.></android.view.View__In this case, the pervade_decrypt() function is clearly written in order to support a data format migration from the original implementation to the new format.><android.view.View__To their credit, pervade_encrypt() only writes the new format, so they clearly intended to retire the old message format eventually. However, they never took the time to learn the proper way to handle cryptographic migrations.></android.view.View__To their credit, pervade_encrypt() only writes the new format, so they clearly intended to retire the old message format eventually. However, they never took the time to learn the proper way to handle cryptographic migrations.><android.view.View__Vulnerabilities in the Decrypt Function></android.view.View__Vulnerabilities in the Decrypt Function><android.view.View__Downgrade Attack></android.view.View__Downgrade Attack><android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.></android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.><android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=></android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=><android.view.View__Base64-decode it. Remove the value between the first ::and the second :: (including one of the separators).></android.view.View__Base64-decode it. Remove the value between the first ::and the second :: (including one of the separators).><android.view.View__Re-encode it with base64, then feed this altered message into the system.></android.view.View__Re-encode it with base64, then feed this altered message into the system.><android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=></android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=><android.view.View__Exploit Code></android.view.View__Exploit Code><android.view.View__function exploit1(string $chosen): string {
    $pieces = explode('::', base64_decode($chosen));
    unset($pieces[1]);
    return base64_encode(implode('::', $pieces));
}
></android.view.View__function exploit1(string $chosen): string {
    $pieces = explode('::', base64_decode($chosen));
    unset($pieces[1]);
    return base64_encode(implode('::', $pieces));
}
><android.view.View__Now you’ve successfully downgraded the message to the legacy format, which didn’t provide any authentication over the ciphertext.></android.view.View__Now you’ve successfully downgraded the message to the legacy format, which didn’t provide any authentication over the ciphertext.><android.view.View__HMAC Verification Bypass></android.view.View__HMAC Verification Bypass><android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.></android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.><android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=></android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=><android.view.View__Base64-decode it. The Unity remix is progressively replacing GNOME components, such as the text editor and file manager, with ones from other desktop projects, in order to get back features which GNOME has removed – notably, menu bars.><android.view.View__So Ubuntu Unity 22.04 uses the Nemo file manager from the Cinnamon desktop, rather than GNOME's Nautilus, and MATE's Pluma text editor instead of GEdit. As a small example, the update makes right-clicking the trashcan in the Launcher to empty it work again, without needing to open the trashcan's own window.></android.view.View__So Ubuntu Unity 22.04 uses the Nemo file manager from the Cinnamon desktop, rather than GNOME's Nautilus, and MATE's Pluma text editor instead of GEdit. The GNOME Shell is still installed, although it doesn't appear on the login menu. The remix uses the GNOME system monitor, which has no menu bar – possibly because the MATE one works fine, but doesn't show up in the app launcher. In the volume control, scrolling down increases the volume, and up decreases it, the opposite of what we expected. And on the accessibility front, several apps' menu bars don't respond to keyboard controls, including the terminal.></android.view.View__The remix still has a few small rough edges. In the volume control, scrolling down increases the volume, and up decreases it, the opposite of what we expected. like><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Sun 3 Jul 2022 // 09:33 UTC China’s efforts to end its reliance on Microsoft Windows got a boost with the launch of the openKylin project. The  aims to accelerate development of the country’s home-grown Kylin Linux distro by opening the project up to a broader community of developers, colleges, and universities to contribute code. Launched in 2001, Kylin was based on a FreeBSD kernel and was intended for use in government and military offices, where Chinese authorities have repeatedly attempted to eliminate foreign operating systems.><android.view.View__China rallies support for Kylin Linux in war on Windows openKylin project is latest chapter in Beijing's love-hate relationship with Redmond></android.view.View__China The starred entries in the list of  are the best supported and should have no show-stopping problems. This is the fourth release of , and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04. Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. Core has no conventional package manager, just Snap, and the OS itself is built from Snap packages. Snap installations and updates are transactional: this means that either they succeed completely, or the OS automatically rolls them back, leaving no trace except an entry in a log file.><android.view.View__Ubuntu releases Core 22: Its IoT and edge distro A tougher nut to crack than the regular flavor, some will find it very tasty></android.view.View__Ubuntu releases Core 22: Its IoT and edge distro A tougher nut to crack than the regular flavor, some will find it very tasty><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Fri 17 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Fri 17 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__07:33 UTC></android.view.View__07:33 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out.></android.view.View__Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This is the fourth release of ></android.view.View__This is the fourth release of ><android.view.View__Ubuntu Core></android.view.View__Ubuntu Core><android.view.View__, and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04.></android.view.View__, and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. As the name suggests, it's made in America – all the electronics are assembled in its Carlsbad, California facility, using as many US-fabricated parts as possible. While past privacy-focused phones, such as 's Android-based Blackphone failed to win much market share, the political situation is different now than it was seven years ago. Supply-chain provenance has become more important in recent years, thanks to concerns about the national security implications of foreign-made tech gear. The  comes at a cost, starting at $1,999, though there are now US government agencies willing to pay that price for homegrown hardware they can trust – and evidently tech enthusiasts, too.><android.view.View__The App Gap and supply chains: Purism CEO on what's ahead for the Librem 5 USA Freedoms eroded, iOS-Android duopoly under fire, chip sources questioned – it's all an opportunity for this phone></android.view.View__The App Gap and supply chains: Purism CEO on what's ahead for the Librem 5 USA Freedoms eroded, iOS-Android duopoly under fire, chip sources questioned – it's all an opportunity for this phone><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Thomas Claburn in San Francisco></android.view.View__Thomas Claburn in San Francisco><android.view.View__Sat 2 Jul 2022 ></android.view.View__Sat 2 Jul 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__10:07 UTC></android.view.View__10:07 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Interview In June, Purism began shipping a privacy-focused smartphone called Librem 5 USA that runs on a version of Linux called PureOS rather than Android or iOS. As the name suggests, it's made in America – all the electronics are assembled in its Carlsbad, California facility, using as many US-fabricated parts as possible. While past privacy-focused phones, such as 's Android-based Blackphone failed to win much market share, the political situation is different now than it was seven years ago. Supply-chain provenance has become more important in recent years, thanks to concerns about the national security implications of foreign-made tech gear. The  comes at a cost, starting at $1,999, though there are now US government agencies willing to pay that price for homegrown hardware they can trust – and evidently tech enthusiasts, too.><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 // 13:40 UTC Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release. The flaw is tracked as , an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. An attacker would need read/write access to the cluster as well as the ability to execute code within a Linux container granted access to the Service Fabric runtime in order to wreak havoc. Through a compromised container, for instance, a miscreant could gain control of the resource's host Service Fabric node and potentially the entire cluster.><android.view.View__FabricScape: Microsoft warns of vuln in Service Fabric Not trying to spin this as a Linux security hole, surely?></android.view.View__FabricScape: Microsoft warns of vuln in Service Fabric Not trying to spin this as a Linux security hole, surely?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Richard Speed></android.view.View__Richard Speed><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__13:40 UTC></android.view.View__13:40 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release.></android.view.View__Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The flaw is tracked as ></android.view.View__The flaw is tracked as ><android.view.View__CVE-2022-30137></android.view.View__CVE-2022-30137><android.view.View__, an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. The flaw is tracked as , an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. Through a compromised container, for instance, a miscreant could gain control of the resource's host Service Fabric node and potentially the entire cluster.><android.view.View__Thu 23 Jun 2022 // 19:30 UTC At The Linux Foundation's Open Source Summit in Austin, Texas on Tuesday, Linus Torvalds said he expects support for Rust code in the Linux kernel to be merged soon, possibly with the next release, 5.20. At least since last December, when  added support for Rust as a second language for kernel code, the Linux community has been anticipating this transition, in the hope it leads to greater stability and security. In a conversation with Dirk Hohndel, chief open source officer at Cardano, Torvalds said the patches to integrate Rust have not yet been merged because there's far more caution among Linux kernel maintainers than there was 30 years ago.><android.view.View__Linus Torvalds says Rust is coming to the Linux kernel 'real soon now' Maintainer lack of familiarity won't be an issue, chief insists, citing his own bafflement when faced with Perl></android.view.View__Linus Torvalds says Rust is coming to the Linux kernel 'real soon now' Maintainer lack of familiarity won't be an issue, chief READING></android.view.View__CONTINUE READING></android.view.View__Thu 23 Jun 2022 // 19:30 UTC At The Linux Foundation's Open Source Summit in Austin, Texas on Tuesday, Linus Torvalds said he expects support for Rust code in the Linux kernel to be merged soon, possibly with the next release, 5.20. At least since last December, when  added support for Rust as a second language for kernel code, the Linux community has been anticipating this transition, in the hope it leads to greater stability and security. In a conversation with Dirk Hohndel, chief open source officer at Cardano, Torvalds said the patches to integrate Rust have not yet been merged because there's far more caution among Linux kernel maintainers than there was 30 years ago.></android.widget.ListView__><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 // 11:39 UTC  is a rolling-release Linux distro based on . Although the project is relatively new, having started in 2019, it's the successor to an earlier Arch-based distro called Antergos, so it's not quite as immature as its youth might imply. It's a little more vanilla than Antergos was – for instance, it uses the Calamares cross-distro installer. EndeavourOS hews more closely to its parent distro than, for example, Manjaro, which we . Unlike Manjaro, it doesn't have its own staging repositories or releases. It installs packages directly from the upstream Arch repositories, using the standard Arch package manager pacman. It also bundles  to easily fetch packages from the Arch User Repository, . The yay command takes the same switches as pacman does, so if you wanted to install, say, Google Chrome, it's as simple as yay -s google-chrome and a few seconds later, it's done.><android.view.View__EndeavourOS Artemis: Arch Linux, but a bit friendlier The Reg FOSS desk takes the latest release, 22.6, for a spin></android.view.View__EndeavourOS Artemis: Arch Linux, but a bit friendlier The Reg FOSS desk takes the latest release, 22.6, for a spin><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__11:39 UTC></android.view.View__11:39 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__EndeavourOS></android.view.View__EndeavourOS><android.view.View__ is a rolling-release Linux distro based on ></android.view.View__ is a rolling-release Linux distro based on ><android.view.View__Arch Linux></android.view.View__Arch Linux><android.view.View__. Although the project is relatively new, having started in 2019, it's the successor to an earlier Arch-based distro called Antergos, so it's not quite as immature as its youth might imply. It's a little more vanilla than Antergos was – for instance, it uses the Calamares cross-distro installer. EndeavourOS hews more closely to its parent distro than, for example, Manjaro, which we . Unlike Manjaro, it doesn't have its own staging repositories or releases. It installs packages directly from the upstream Arch repositories, using the standard Arch package manager pacman. It also bundles  to easily fetch packages from the Arch User Repository, . The yay command takes the same switches as pacman does, so if you wanted to install, say, Google Chrome, it's as simple as yay -s google-chrome and a few seconds later, it's done.><android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 // 18:30 UTC Microsoft has made it official. Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 distributions are now supported on Windows Server 2022. The  in preview form last month and represented somewhat of an about-face from the Windows giant, whose employees had previously complained that while the tech was handy for desktop users, sticking it on a server might mean it gets used for things for which it wasn't intended. (And Windows Server absolutely had to have the bloated user interface of its desktop stablemate as well, right?)><android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 // 14:59 UTC Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.  has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, . The goal is to "drastically" improve the performance of Vim scripts, while also bringing the scripting language more into line with widely used languages such as JavaScript, TypeScript, and Java. The existing scripting language, Vimscript, remains and will still work. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.><android.view.View__Old-school editor Vim hits version 9 with faster scripting language All of the famed user-friendliness and ease of use – and 'drastically' better performance></android.view.View__Old-school editor Vim hits version 9 with faster scripting language All of the famed user-friendliness and ease of use – and 'drastically' better performance><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__14:59 UTC></android.view.View__14:59 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.></android.view.View__Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Vim 9></android.view.View__Vim 9><android.view.View__ has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, ></android.view.View__ has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, ><android.view.View__Vim9script></android.view.View__Vim9script><android.view.View__. The goal is to "drastically" improve the performance of Vim scripts, while also bringing the scripting language more into line with widely used languages such as JavaScript, TypeScript, and Java. The existing scripting language, Vimscript, remains and will still work. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.><android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 // 08:30 UTC Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one. Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new  is the latest update to version 21, released in 2021. There are three official variants, with GNOME 42.2, KDE 5.24.5 or Xfce 4.16 desktops, plus community builds with Budgie, Cinnamon, MATE, a choice of tiling window managers (i3 or Sway), plus a Docker image. The Reg took its  a few months ago. Arch is one of the older rolling-release distros, and it's also famously rather minimal. The installation process isn't trivial: it's driven from the command line, and the user does a lot of the hard work, manually partitioning disks and so on.><android.view.View__Leading Arch Linux derivative Manjaro puts out version 21.3 A simpler, easier remix sounds like a good thing, but glitches like these shouldn't be in a point release></android.view.View__Leading Arch Linux derivative Manjaro puts out version 21.3 A simpler, easier remix sounds like a good thing, but glitches like these shouldn't be in a point release><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__08:30 UTC></android.view.View__08:30 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one.></android.view.View__Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new ></android.view.View__Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new ><android.view.View__version 21.3></android.view.View__version 21.3><android.view.View__ is the latest update to version 21, released in 2021. She wrote about what made a blog different:><android.view.View__><android.view.View__No one wants to scroll down to the bottom of the page (or even the current day’s section) to see if any new content has been posted. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.></android.view.View__Not having an RSS item title might take some getting used to for mainstream blogging clients and readers. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.><android.view.View__The specific rule for post length or which feeds you include can be useful. These should be thought of as more of a guideline than a rule, though — just something to shoot for.></android.view.View__The specific rule for post length or which feeds you include can be useful. These should be thought of as more of a guideline than a rule, though — just something to shoot for.><android.view.View__We focus on microblogging because it’s the easiest form of web publishing. centralized platforms create problems for society. By posting to your own site, you control your content, distributing it more evenly across the web and minimizing the power of big tech companies.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Massive centralized platforms create problems for society. By posting to your own site, you control your content, distributing it more evenly across the web and minimizing the power of big tech companies.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__This might seem like too much work for most people. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.></android.view.View__This might seem like too much work for most people. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.><android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.></android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.><android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.></android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.><android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.></android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.><android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:></android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:><android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.></android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.><android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.></android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.><android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. It can be hosted by multiple providers, but it is conceptually independent of any one platform. It’s portable and you control it.></android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. It can be hosted by multiple providers, but it is conceptually independent of any one platform. It’s portable and you control it.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Next: Uses for a microblog →></android.view.View__Next: Uses for a microblog →></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.webkit.WebView__What is microblogging? · Indie Microblogging></android.webkit.WebView__></android.view.ViewGroup_com.hexforhn.hex:webview_layout_></android.support.v4.view.ViewPager_com.hexforhn.hex:pager_></android.widget.LinearLayout__></android.widget.FrameLayout_android:content_></android.widget.LinearLayout_com.hexforhn.hex:action_bar_root_></android.widget.FrameLayout__></android.widget.LinearLayout__><android.view.View_android:statusBarBackground_></android.view.View_android:statusBarBackground_><android.view.View_android:navigationBarBackground_></android.view.View_android:navigationBarBackground_></android.widget.FrameLayout__></_NO_ID_null>

></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__My son is 12 y/o, and he's into Minecraft.></android.view.View__My son is 12 y/o, and he's into Minecraft.><android.view.View__Yesterday he discovered the server mc.openredstone.org. He spent all day yesterday and about one hour today, and he ended up building a 4-bit adder.></android.view.View__Yesterday he discovered the server mc.openredstone.org. He spent all day yesterday and about one hour today, and he ended up building a 4-bit adder.><android.view.View__On this server players learn how to build logic gates, and mix them so they eventually build CPUs. It's fully gamified, so beginners are called "students" and more advanced players are called "builders". To become a "builder" you need to pass some trials. The "builders" probably have their own challenges (not sure, my son is still a student), in any case, they behave like teachers. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.></android.view.View__On this server players learn how to build logic gates, and mix them so they eventually build CPUs. It's fully gamified, so beginners are called "students" and more advanced players are called "builders". To become a "builder" you need to pass some trials. The "builders" probably have their own challenges (not sure, my son is still a student), in any case, they behave like teachers. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.><android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.></android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.><android.view.View__I'm quite excited to be honest. By the way, I'm not in any way connected with whomever put together this Minecraft server. I don't even think it's a for-profit thing, as far as I can tell, it's fully non-profit.></android.view.View__I'm quite excited to be honest. I keep an eye on what he’s doing there, which is quite easy, as he just won’t stop talking about it. It’s also an opportunity for me to teach him, but in a way that he finds exciting. If one day I had decided to teach him XOR or NAND, he would’ve found it very boring. This way, he comes to me with questions, and I can pick up a piece of paper and show him what a truth table is, and he soaks it up. Mom's attempts to do so are met with less enthusiasm.><android.view.View__----></android.view.View__----><android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. In plain words, it's like this: mom can't give him her full attention; the world and society and large steal her from him. Luckily, the baby learns to personify all this stuff into dad -- it's dad who steals mommy. This is lucky because he can aspire to be me, while "society at large" is enough to drive anyone insane. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. He attentively watches me as I dress, and enjoys enormously the homologies (hey, let's all put on socks!). Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. (Jacques Lacan has this pun where "le non du pere" becomes "le nom du pere" -- baby will have my name, this is the heart of fathering.)></android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. Sean of the South><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sean of the South></android.view.View__Sean of the South></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.widget.ListView__></android.widget.ListView__></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__SEAN OF THE SOUTH></android.view.View__SEAN OF THE SOUTH></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Mendon, Missouri></android.view.View__Mendon, Missouri><android.view.View__><android.view.View__SEAN DIETRICH></android.view.View__SEAN DIETRICH><android.view.View__JULY 3, 2022></android.view.View__JULY 3, 2022></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__CA88780C-F048-4CAE-B3C0-A1DE08F634E1></android.view.View__CA88780C-F048-4CAE-B3C0-A1DE08F634E1></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Mendon, Missouri. Population 171. There’s really nothing here. The tiny town is located off Route 11, just south of Yellow Creek. You’re three hours west of Saint Louis, two hours east of Kansas City.></android.view.View__Mendon, Missouri. Population 171. There’s really nothing here. The tiny town is located off Route 11, just south of Yellow Creek. You’re three hours west of Saint Louis, two hours east of Kansas City.><android.view.View__It’s quiet. No attractions. No major landmarks. Nobody famous ever lived here unless you count Vern Kennedy, right-hander for the White Sox, circa 1934.></android.view.View__It’s quiet. No attractions. No major landmarks. Nobody famous ever lived here unless you count Vern Kennedy, right-hander for the White Sox, circa 1934.><android.view.View__If you’re looking for entertainment in Mendon, your main option is Busch Light. But you’ll have to drive all the way to Brunswick to find a liquor store.></android.view.View__If you’re looking for entertainment in Mendon, your main option is Busch Light. But you’ll have to drive all the way to Brunswick to find a liquor store.><android.view.View__“We are just country folk,” said Mendon native Carol Ann Wamsley, “and that’s what makes us a special place.”></android.view.View__“We are just country folk,” said Mendon native Carol Ann Wamsley, “and that’s what makes us a special place.”><android.view.View__At its heart, Mendon is a railroad town. The first iron tracks were laid in 1887. Within a decade, a town sprang up. You had a few dozen storefronts, a school, a newspaper, and a couple churches with steeply conflicting views on eternal damnation. Most of that is gone now.></android.view.View__At its heart, Mendon is a railroad town. The first iron tracks were laid in 1887. Within a decade, a town sprang up. You had a few dozen storefronts, a school, a newspaper, and a couple churches with steeply conflicting views on eternal damnation. Most of that is gone now.><android.view.View__Today, the Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad line still passes the northwest side of the community, only now it’s the Southern Transcon Railroad.></android.view.View__Today, the Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad line still passes the northwest side of the community, only now it’s the Southern Transcon Railroad.><android.view.View__The Amtrak Southwest Chief runs through town regularly. On summer afternoons you can see the Amtrak locomotive in the distance, racing across the prairie like a polished chromium bullet. But the train never stops here. It just keeps moving.></android.view.View__The Amtrak Southwest Chief runs through town regularly. On summer afternoons you can see the Amtrak locomotive in the distance, racing across the prairie like a polished chromium bullet. But the train never stops here. It just keeps moving.><android.view.View__Until last week.></android.view.View__Until last week.><android.view.View__It was a Monday that will live in infamy. The Southwest Chief made an unexpected stop near Mendon, of all places.></android.view.View__It was a Monday that will live in infamy. The Southwest Chief made an unexpected stop near Mendon, of all places.><android.view.View__The Chief was traveling 87 mph, bound for Chicago. There were more people aboard than there are living within Mendon’s city limits.></android.view.View__The Chief was traveling 87 mph, bound for Chicago. There were more people aboard than there are living within Mendon’s city limits.><android.view.View__Up ahead a dump truck was on the tracks. The truck was obstructing the crossing of County Road 113. This was not a small truck. This was a vehicle about the size of a Sonic Drive-In.></android.view.View__Up ahead a dump truck was on the tracks. The truck was obstructing the crossing of County Road 113. This was not a small truck. This was a vehicle about the size of a Sonic Drive-In.><android.view.View__The train never slowed.></android.view.View__The train never slowed.><android.view.View__The sound of the collision could be heard from as far away as Westville. It was the noise of two General Electric diesel locomotives and seven Superliner cars plowing into a mass of Dearborn steel. The train was derailed.></android.view.View__The sound of the collision could be heard from as far away as Westville. It was the noise of two General Electric diesel locomotives and seven Superliner cars plowing into a mass of Dearborn steel. The train was derailed.><android.view.View__Ron Goulet was riding coach.></android.view.View__Ron Goulet was riding coach.><android.view.View__“…I was airborne. Everything was tumbling. People on top of people. The train rolled on its right side—the entire train, except for the front locomotive.”></android.view.View__“…I was airborne. Everything was tumbling. People on top of people. The train rolled on its right side—the entire train, except for the front locomotive.”><android.view.View__Carry-on bags went everywhere. Elbows collided with craniums. Shoes crashed into jaws. Children clashed against the ceiling.></android.view.View__Carry-on bags went everywhere. Elbows collided with craniums. Shoes crashed into jaws. Children clashed against the ceiling.><android.view.View__“When I climbed up and out of the train…” said Ron, “I was stunned that the entire thing was lying on its side. Not in a jumbled mass, but all laid over on the side.”></android.view.View__“When I climbed up and out of the train…” said Ron, “I was stunned that the entire thing was lying on its side. Not in a jumbled mass, but all laid over on the side.”><android.view.View__The story made national headlines, of course. Reporters from national newspapers visited. They photographed, videoed and wrote. Cable news anchors wore frowny faces and mentioned the wreck, just before cutting to commercials urging elderly viewers to reverse mortgage their livers.></android.view.View__The story made national headlines, of course. Reporters from national newspapers visited. They photographed, videoed and wrote. Cable news anchors wore frowny faces and mentioned the wreck, just before cutting to commercials urging elderly viewers to reverse mortgage their livers.><android.view.View__But somehow, the bigger story about what happened in Mendon was lost. Somehow, you didn’t hear about Mendon’s magnificent people.></android.view.View__But somehow, the bigger story about what happened in Mendon was lost. Somehow, you didn’t hear about Mendon’s magnificent people.><android.view.View__Sure, you heard about the wreck itself; the 150 injured, and the four fatalities. But you didn’t hear about how the residents of Mendon—nearly every single resident—rushed to the scene of the accident.></android.view.View__Sure, you heard about the wreck itself; the 150 injured, and the four fatalities. But you didn’t hear about how the residents of Mendon—nearly every single resident—rushed to the scene of the accident.><android.view.View__Throngs of ordinary townspeople arrived before first responders even knew about the crash. There were volunteers crawling out of the wallpaper.></android.view.View__Throngs of ordinary townspeople arrived before first responders even knew about the crash. There were volunteers crawling out of the wallpaper.><android.view.View__“It was a wonderful problem to have,” said school district superintendent, Eric Hoyt, “but we probably had too many volunteers show up.”></android.view.View__“It was a wonderful problem to have,” said school district superintendent, Eric Hoyt, “but we probably had too many volunteers show up.”><android.view.View__People came from all over Chariton County, riding beat-up Silverados, ATVs, or arriving on foot. They came from Sumner, Marceline, Cunningham, Brookfield and Indian Grove.></android.view.View__People came from all over Chariton County, riding beat-up Silverados, ATVs, or arriving on foot. They came from Sumner, Marceline, Cunningham, Brookfield and Indian Grove.><android.view.View__Two Boy Scout troops dutifully helped injured victims from the wreckage. Local high-schoolers were fashioning bandages out of bandannas. Old women recited the Lord’s Prayer alongside strangers in blood-stained clothes.></android.view.View__Two Boy Scout troops dutifully helped injured victims from the wreckage. Local high-schoolers were fashioning bandages out of bandannas. Old women recited the Lord’s Prayer alongside strangers in blood-stained clothes.><android.view.View__There were farmers, off-duty nurses, truck drivers, soccer moms, Little League coaches and grade-schoolers. They were doling out food, first aid, bottled water and, most importantly, phone chargers.></android.view.View__There were farmers, off-duty nurses, truck drivers, soccer moms, Little League coaches and grade-schoolers. They were doling out food, first aid, bottled water and, most importantly, phone chargers.><android.view.View__Victims were taken to local homes, fed, bathed and bandaged. Weeping passengers were embraced by rural preachers. Passengers using wheelchairs were lifted from the rubble by young men in ropers and camouflage caps.></android.view.View__Victims were taken to local homes, fed, bathed and bandaged. Weeping passengers were embraced by rural preachers. Passengers using wheelchairs were lifted from the rubble by young men in ropers and camouflage caps.><android.view.View__Local schoolbus drivers transported the wounded to hospitals. Northwestern High School staff members triaged victims in the gymnasium and fed people in the cafeteria.></android.view.View__Local schoolbus drivers transported the wounded to hospitals. Northwestern High School staff members triaged victims in the gymnasium and fed people in the cafeteria.><android.view.View__One resident said that Mendon didn’t feel like a 171-person town anymore. “It was like 671 people came together.”></android.view.View__One resident said that Mendon didn’t feel like a 171-person town anymore. “It was like 671 people came together.”><android.view.View__And the most unusual thing about all this is: None of this is unusual. At least not within the national tapestry that is The Great American Small Town.></android.view.View__And the most unusual thing about all this is: None of this is unusual. At least not within the national tapestry that is The Great American Small Town.><android.view.View__Although we rarely hear about such acts of compassion and lovingkindness within our society, believe me, they happen. Maybe part of our problem as Americans is we don’t have something big to bring us together. We’re in each other’s faces instead of working side-by-side, shoulder-to-shoulder to solve some really urgent problems. There are plenty of them. But those sad faces in the media and our political leadership on both sides has us squared off against each other. We don’t need a train wreck or all the heart ache that causes, for goodness sake. But it sure seems like we need to come together on a common effort before we wreck this train we’re on. When we’re faced with really tough things we find out we’re a nation of small towns like Mendon, even if it’s as big as New York City, or Minneapolis, or Los Angelos. ><android.view.View__Lander - July 3, 2022 11:23 am></android.view.View__Lander - July 3, 2022 11:23 am><android.view.View__Thanks, Sean. It’s nice to be reminded in times like these. ><android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! Thank you for highlighting this example of the folks of Mendon, part of the backbone of our country.
I was deeply formed by growing up in a Great Small Town of America. In our metropolis of 450 people, a tiny farming community in East central Illinois, our family home on the edge of town was nestled in between corn fields on two sides and a railroad on the third, with the front of the house facing the street.
My earliest memories include the Christmas season that our house caught on fire while many people–including our family of eight–were visiting Santa Claus up at the firehouse as the call came in. Nobody had to ask for volunteers to help put out the flames or tend to us children while our parents focused on salvaging belongings, because the whole town immediately moved en masse to our front yard to help out in any way they could.
We were fed and clothed and housed by our fellow townspeople until Mom found a place for us to stay while Dad and friends built our new home over the ashes of our old one.
I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me. ><android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm></android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! ><android.view.View__I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me.></android.view.View__I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! Thank you for highlighting this example of the folks of Mendon, part of the backbone of our country.
I was deeply formed by growing up in a Great Small Town of America. In our metropolis of 450 people, a tiny farming community in East central Illinois, our family home on the edge of town was nestled in between corn fields on two sides and a railroad on the third, with the front of the house facing the street.
My earliest memories include the Christmas season that our house caught on fire while many people–including our family of eight–were visiting Santa Claus up at the firehouse as the call came in. Nobody had to ask for volunteers to help put out the flames or tend to us children while our parents focused on salvaging belongings, because the whole town immediately moved en masse to our front yard to help out in any way they could.
We were fed and clothed and housed by our fellow townspeople until Mom found a place for us to stay while Dad and friends built our new home over the ashes of our old one.
I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me. ><android.view.View__David Britnell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm I think small town USA people have more of a sense of community in general. I can ask almost anyone in my little town of Hardy, AR for help and I would have no trouble getting it. Ever been to Clio, South Carolina? Pronounced Clyoh. Small town on a short-cut to Myrtle Beach from Charlotte. Name came from ‘Stop Number Ten on the old Coast Line — CL ten — CLIO. If you are ever there, check out an old plantation house called ‘Harleanton’, bought and restored by Dr. Harley Davidson. Harley’s widow or maybe his son probably still live there. ><android.view.View__Bob Wasson - July 3, 2022 4:09 pm></android.view.View__Bob Wasson - July 3, 2022 4:09 pm><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Hi Sean,></android.view.View__Hi Sean,><android.view.View__

><android.view.View__Ever been to Clio, South Carolina? Pronounced Clyoh. Small town on a short-cut to Myrtle Beach from Charlotte. Name came from ‘Stop Number Ten on the old Coast Line — CL ten — CLIO. If you are ever there, check out an old plantation house called ‘Harleanton’, bought and restored by Dr. Harley Davidson. Harley’s widow or maybe his son probably still live there.></android.view.View__Ever been to Clio, South Carolina? Pronounced Clyoh. Small town on a short-cut to Myrtle Beach from Charlotte. Name came from ‘Stop Number Ten on the old Coast Line — CL ten — CLIO. If you are ever there, check out an old plantation house called ‘Harleanton’, bought and restored by Dr. Harley Davidson. Harley’s widow or maybe his son probably still live there.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__Bob Wasson - July 3, 2022 4:09 pm Hi Sean,
Ever been to Clio, South Carolina? Pronounced Clyoh. Small town on a short-cut to Myrtle Beach from Charlotte. Name came from ‘Stop Number Ten on the old Coast Line — CL ten — CLIO. If you are ever there, check out an old plantation house called ‘Harleanton’, bought and restored by Dr. Harley Davidson. Harley’s widow or maybe his son probably still live there. ><android.view.View__Patricia Gibson - July 3, 2022 4:12 pm Thank you, Sean! YOU probably shouldn't use Kubernetes and a bunch of other "cool" things for your product.></android.view.View__It feels bizarre saying this, having spent so much of my life advocating for and selling a distribution of Kubernetes and consulting services to help folks get the most of out it, but here goes! YOU probably shouldn't use Kubernetes and a bunch of other "cool" things for your product.><android.view.View__Most folks building software at startups and scale-ups should avoid Kubernetes and other premature optimisations. If your company uses Kubernetes, you are likely expending energy on something that doesn't take you towards your mission. You have probably fallen into the trap of premature optimisation.></android.view.View__Most folks building software at startups and scale-ups should avoid Kubernetes and other premature optimisations. If your company uses Kubernetes, you are likely expending energy on something that doesn't take you towards your mission. You have probably fallen into the trap of premature optimisation.><android.view.View__Please don't take this post to be only aimed against Kubernetes. It is not. I am directing this post at every possible bit of premature optimisation engineers make in the course of building software.></android.view.View__Please don't take this post to be only aimed against Kubernetes. It is not. I am directing this post at every possible bit of premature optimisation engineers make in the course of building software.><android.view.View__Here are a few examples I've seen:></android.view.View__Here are a few examples I've seen:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.></android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.></android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.><android.view.View__More than one language for your application. Most product teams will have over-architected their solution if they have to have an ops or infra team.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Not using a cloud service to host your app. Examples are Heroku, Vercel, Netlify and ></android.view.View__Not using a cloud service to host your app. Examples are Heroku, Vercel, Netlify and ><android.view.View__Fly.io></android.view.View__Fly.io><android.view.View__. Most product teams will have over-architected their solution if they have to have an ops or infra team.></android.view.View__Not using a cloud service to host your app. Examples are Heroku, Vercel, Netlify and . Most product teams will have over-architected their solution if they have to have an ops or infra team.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Imagine spending a lot of time and money picking out the best possible gear for a hobby before actually starting the hobby.></android.view.View__Imagine spending a lot of time and money picking out the best possible gear for a hobby before actually starting the hobby.><android.view.View__Some of this is subjective, of course. Perhaps you know you will stick with your new hobby for a long time, and you have a friend who is an expert at your new hobby who can help you pick the right gear. I have to admit I'm good at justifying the elite-level equipment for myself, even though I might never really notice the difference.></android.view.View__Some of this is subjective, of course. Perhaps you know you will stick with your new hobby for a long time, and you have a friend who is an expert at your new hobby who can help you pick the right gear. I have to admit I'm good at justifying the elite-level equipment for myself, even though I might never really notice the difference.><android.view.View__Your organisation needs engineers to create an impact on the mission.></android.view.View__Your organisation needs engineers to create an impact on the mission.><android.view.View__If you are in a place where you think you need Kubernetes, then you are probably in a place where you are trying to optimise for the future prematurely. A future that probably won't happen. If you adopt any technology, you are making a multi-year commitment for your organisation that will increase the surface area of your product and the cognitive load on your developers. Eventually, you will have to create a dedicated team to maintain it. All of this takes resources away from your core mission.></android.view.View__If you are in a place where you think you need Kubernetes, then you are probably in a place where you are trying to optimise for the future prematurely. A future that probably won't happen. If you adopt any technology, you are making a multi-year commitment for your organisation that will increase the surface area of your product and the cognitive load on your developers. Eventually, you will have to create a dedicated team to maintain it. All of this takes resources away from your core mission.><android.view.View__It is easy for engineers to slip into this trap. We are all magpies distracted by the new shiny. We want to learn and grow, and the best way to do that is to incorporate the latest tech into our product. Then, we can come up with all sorts of reasons that justify our decisions.></android.view.View__It is easy for engineers to slip into this trap. We are all magpies distracted by the new shiny. We want to learn and grow, and the best way to do that is to incorporate the latest tech into our product. Then, we can come up with all sorts of reasons that justify our decisions.><android.view.View__Let me tell you some stories of how I have fallen into this trap.></android.view.View__Let me tell you some stories of how I have fallen into this trap.><android.view.View__I remember a discussion when I joined OCUS and discovered we were using Kubernetes. I said something to the tune of, "oh, that is great. One day, we might want to leave AWS and having Kubernetes will help us with that". Can you see how crazy I was at that moment?></android.view.View__I remember a discussion when I joined OCUS and discovered we were using Kubernetes. I said something to the tune of, "oh, that is great. One day, we might want to leave AWS and having Kubernetes will help us with that". Can you see how crazy I was at that moment?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Another time our Data Science team told us that they needed an orchestration tool for their data pipelines. I steered the selection process towards ></android.view.View__Another time our Data Science team told us that they needed an orchestration tool for their data pipelines. I steered the selection process towards ><android.view.View__Argo Workflows></android.view.View__Argo Workflows><android.view.View__(which runs inside Kubernetes) instead of ></android.view.View__(which runs inside Kubernetes) instead of ><android.view.View__Prefect></android.view.View__Prefect><android.view.View__ (a SaaS offering), which they already used for a PoC. There were all sorts of justifications in my head for this decision. Unfortunately, they were all based on premature optimisations. In the end, our team needed to build a new set of Terraform and Helm charts to automate the deployment of Argo Workflows and integrate it into our SSO etc. I regret this decision. I think we lost weeks or even months shipping something to end-users because of this decision. Premature optimisation!></android.view.View__ (a SaaS offering), which they already used for a PoC. There were all sorts of justifications in my head for this decision. Unfortunately, they were all based on premature optimisations. In the end, our team needed to build a new set of Terraform and Helm charts to automate the deployment of Argo Workflows and integrate it into our SSO etc. I regret this decision. I think we lost weeks or even months shipping something to end-users because of this decision. Premature optimisation!></android.view.View__><android.view.View__If we can dodge premature optimisations, we will move faster than our competitors, please our users and increase our chances of building a sustainable and viable product.></android.view.View__If we can dodge premature optimisations, we will move faster than our competitors, please our users and increase our chances of building a sustainable and viable product.><android.view.View__So how can we break out of this thinking?></android.view.View__So how can we break out of this thinking?><android.view.View__Did users ask for this?></android.view.View__Did users ask for this?><android.view.View__Solve problems as they arise, not in advance. The work we do should solve the user's issues. Ask yourself,what is the human behaviour I'm trying to impact with my work?></android.view.View__Solve problems as they arise, not in advance. The work we do should solve the user's issues. Ask yourself,what is the human behaviour I'm trying to impact with my work?><android.view.View__If you can remain laser-focused on impacting user behaviour and only solve real problems when they come up, you will surprise yourself with the impact you can have. You might also surprise yourself with how many assumptions you make about users because you haven't talked to them in a long time.></android.view.View__If you can remain laser-focused on impacting user behaviour and only solve real problems when they come up, you will surprise yourself with the impact you can have. You might also surprise yourself with how many assumptions you make about users because you haven't talked to them in a long time.><android.view.View__I believe that companies that stick to this approach rigorously will create greater leverage and more value for their users and shareholders.></android.view.View__I believe that companies that stick to this approach rigorously will create greater leverage and more value for their users and shareholders.><android.view.View__I will know what I need if I spend all my energy doing my new hobby instead of researching equipment. In the beginning stages, I will not need the most "Gucci" gear, and I might even look out of place if I had the best equipment and no clue how to use it. It would be better to smash others with my entry-level equipment down the line because I spent all my energy learning my new hobby. Then when I did upgrade to the "Gucci" gear, it would make a real difference.></android.view.View__I will know what I need if I spend all my energy doing my new hobby instead of researching equipment. In the beginning stages, I will not need the most "Gucci" gear, and I might even look out of place if I had the best equipment and no clue how to use it. It would be better to smash others with my entry-level equipment down the line because I spent all my energy learning my new hobby. Then when I did upgrade to the "Gucci" gear, it would make a real difference.><android.view.View__Do more with less.></android.view.View__Do more with less.><android.view.View__Thankfully the Tech world is going through a massive course correction. As interest rates increase, cheap debt and Venture Capital is starting to dry up. Now that startups can't access crazy money, they must focus even more on their mission. The companies that survive will be the ones that have solid fundamentals.></android.view.View__Thankfully the Tech world is going through a massive course correction. As interest rates increase, cheap debt and Venture Capital is starting to dry up. Now that startups can't access crazy money, they must focus even more on their mission. The companies that survive will be the ones that have solid fundamentals.><android.view.View__Products will have to be built by smaller teams that can deliver business outcomes at an increasingly faster pace.></android.view.View__Products will have to be built by smaller teams that can deliver business outcomes at an increasingly faster pace.><android.view.View__I can't see a place for Kubernetes in a lean organisation until they have grown to a massive scale. Even then, I think Kubernetes is a stretch. Most organisations should consider some of the higher-level building blocks available via cloud providers.></android.view.View__I can't see a place for Kubernetes in a lean organisation until they have grown to a massive scale. Even then, I think Kubernetes is a stretch. Most organisations should consider some of the higher-level building blocks available via cloud providers.><android.view.View__Remember that when Facebook bought WhatsApp for $19 billion, it had 35 developers and 450 million users!></android.view.View__Remember that when Facebook bought WhatsApp for $19 billion, it had 35 developers and 450 million users!><android.view.View__If there is one takeaway from reading this, it is to be hyper-focused on what you need to achieve your organisation's mission. Don't get distracted by stuff you want to learn like Kubernetes or Golang - save that for the homelab.></android.view.View__If there is one takeaway from reading this, it is to be hyper-focused on what you need to achieve your organisation's mission. Don't get distracted by stuff you want to learn like Kubernetes or Golang - save that for the homelab.><android.view.View__If you can remain hyper-focused on making changes in your product that impact human behaviour that impacts business results, I have no doubt you will smash it out of the park.></android.view.View__If you can remain hyper-focused on making changes in your product that impact human behaviour that impacts business results, I have no doubt you will smash it out of the park.><android.view.View__That is all for this week folks, have a great week!></android.view.View__That is all for this week folks, have a great week!><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Jeremy (he/him)></android.view.View__Jeremy (he/him)></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Don't ignore your While we continuously make iterative improvements to GitLab and our production architecture, we anticipate making a larger change to improve the scalability and reliability of GitLab.com: We are splitting our single PostgreSQL database into a main and a cidatabase.></android.view.View__Improving the performance and reliability of GitLab.com has always been a top priority for GitLab. While we continuously make iterative improvements to GitLab and our production architecture, we anticipate making a larger change to improve the scalability and reliability of GitLab.com: We are splitting our single PostgreSQL database into a main and a cidatabase.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__We believe this process, also known as ></android.view.View__We believe this process, also known as ><android.view.View__functional decomposition></android.view.View__functional decomposition><android.view.View__, will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x and allows GitLab.com to continue to scale.></android.view.View__, will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x and allows GitLab.com to continue to scale.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When will the split take place and what does this mean for users of GitLab.com?></android.view.View__When will the split take place and what does this mean for users of GitLab.com?><android.view.View__This change is planned to take place between Saturday, 2022-07-02, 05:00am UTC and Saturday, 2022-07-02, 09:00am UTC. The implementation of this change is anticipated to include a service downtime of up to 120 minutesbetween Saturday, 2022-07-02, 06:00am to 08:00am UTC. During this time you will experience complete service disruption of GitLab.com.></android.view.View__This change is planned to take place between Saturday, 2022-07-02, 05:00am UTC and Saturday, 2022-07-02, 09:00am UTC. The implementation of this change is anticipated to include a service downtime of up to 120 minutesbetween Saturday, 2022-07-02, 06:00am to 08:00am UTC. During this time you will experience complete service disruption of GitLab.com.><android.view.View__We are taking downtime to ensure that the application works as expected following the split and to minimize the risk of any data integrity issues.></android.view.View__We are taking downtime to ensure that the application works as expected following the split and to minimize the risk of any data integrity issues.><android.view.View__Background></android.view.View__Background><android.view.View__><android.view.View__GitLab.com's ></android.view.View__GitLab.com's ><android.view.View__database architecture></android.view.View__database architecture><android.view.View__ uses a single PostgreSQL database cluster. This single cluster (let's call it ></android.view.View__ uses a single PostgreSQL database cluster. This single cluster (let's call it ><android.view.View__main></android.view.View__main><android.view.View__), consists of a single primary and multiple read-only replicas and stores the data generated by all GitLab features. Database reads can be scaled horizontally through read-only replicas, but writes cannot because PostgreSQL does not support active-active replication natively.></android.view.View__), consists of a single primary and multiple read-only replicas and stores the data generated by all GitLab features. Database reads can be scaled horizontally through read-only replicas, but writes cannot because PostgreSQL does not support active-active replication natively.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__A large portion of all writes are generated by features related to Continuous Integration (CI). So, to scale GitLab.com's database capacity, we are splitting the single PostgreSQL main cluster into two clusters:></android.view.View__A large portion of all writes are generated by features related to Continuous Integration (CI). So, to scale GitLab.com's database capacity, we are splitting the single PostgreSQL main cluster into two clusters:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__A Continuous Integration database into ></android.view.View__Splitting our database into ><android.view.View__main></android.view.View__main><android.view.View__ and ></android.view.View__ and ><android.view.View__ci></android.view.View__ci><android.view.View__ initially will only impact GitLab.com. To ensure consistency, we plan to enable ><android.view.View__decomposition for self-managed GitLab instances></android.view.View__decomposition for self-managed GitLab instances><android.view.View__ later. While this split is a significant architectural change that we believe will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x, there are other benefits as well.></android.view.View__ later. While this split is a significant architectural change that we believe will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x, there are other benefits as well.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Increased performance></android.view.View__Increased performance><android.view.View__By running two separate database clusters, we believe we will increase the overall count of available database connections. This means we can serve more traffic. It also means that during peak hours there is more buffer, which reduces the likelihood of congestion that may cause performance and UX degradations.></android.view.View__By running two separate database clusters, we believe we will increase the overall count of available database connections. This means we can serve more traffic. It also means that during peak hours there is more buffer, which reduces the likelihood of congestion that may cause performance and UX degradations.><android.view.View__Another significant advantage is that we anticipate we will be able to tune the main andci databases independently, allowing us to optimize these different workloads.></android.view.View__Another significant advantage is that we anticipate we will be able to tune the main andci databases independently, allowing us to optimize these different workloads.><android.view.View__Increased stability></android.view.View__Increased stability><android.view.View__Splitting the database cluster into main and cimeans that ci writes are shifting to the cidatabase cluster. We anticipate this will lead to reduced database saturation, which is a major cause of incidents. Consequently, we believe that the overall stability of GitLab.com may increase following the split.></android.view.View__Splitting the database cluster into main and cimeans that ci writes are shifting to the cidatabase cluster. We anticipate this will lead to reduced database saturation, which is a major cause of incidents. Consequently, we believe that the overall stability of GitLab.com may increase following the split.><android.view.View__We believe increased stability means that development teams can spend more time working on generating value through new features and other improvements and less time guarding against potential issues.></android.view.View__We believe increased stability means that development teams can spend more time working on generating value through new features and other improvements and less time guarding against potential issues.><android.view.View__Shipping as fast as ever></android.view.View__Shipping as fast as ever><android.view.View__><android.view.View__A primary objective of this project was to provide tooling to our development teams so that they can continue to develop features that use multiple databases. After all, we will run another database cluster. Given that the ci cluster is almost identical to the existing main cluster, our DBREs and SREs are able to re-use almost all tools (for example for backups) and dashboards. This reduces the overall risk introduced by this change.></android.view.View__This change does introduce additional complexity. After all, we will run another database cluster. Given that the ci cluster is almost identical to the existing main cluster, our DBREs and SREs are able to re-use almost all tools (for example for backups) and dashboards. This reduces the overall risk introduced by this change.><android.view.View__How we are preparing for the split></android.view.View__How we are preparing for the split><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Over the last year, many teams at GitLab have worked to support running GitLab using multiple databases. These rehearsals include dry runs, executing the promotion of the ></android.view.View__ is working closely with our SREs, DBREs and Quality to rehearse for the production change. These rehearsals include dry runs, executing the promotion of the ><android.view.View__ci></android.view.View__ci><android.view.View__ database cluster, and testing our rollback strategies. All of these steps are tracked as part of a CI decomposition change template. This template is continuously improved to ensure that we capture all learnings from the rehearsals. The template is mirrored onto our Ops GitLab instance, which will remain available during the downtime window and forms the basis for executing the change.></android.view.View__ database cluster, and testing our rollback strategies. All of these steps are tracked as part of a CI decomposition change template. This template is continuously improved to ensure that we capture all learnings from the rehearsals. change.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__The general process of the split can be described as follows:></android.view.View__The general process of the split can be described as
